item.title: Rumor: Nintendo Switch Online Could Be Getting DS Games
item.description:
A new patent filing from Nintendo could indicate that a potential DS app is on its way to the Nintendo Switch Online service. The patent, possibly related to Nintendo Switch Online, demonstrated that users could connect one or two Switch consoles wirelessly to emulate the DS' dual-screen controls, or swap between the top and bottom DS screens via a controller input.

Originally released in 2004, the DS family of consoles is Nintendo's best-selling system, having tallied over 154 million units sold as of 2016. The DS released several iterations over its lifespan, starting with the original "fat DS" model and later including the DS Lite and DSi systems. The DS was known for its two screens, with the bottom one having touch input controls. The original DS and DS Lite also included a Game Boy Advance cartridge slot for backward compatibility. The DS was also the home of two mainline Pokemon game generations, from Pokemon Diamond and Pearl to Pokemon Black 2 and White 2 .

Nintendo Patent Could Lead to DS Games Coming to Switch Online

Although Nintendo has filed patents concerning DS-inspired systems, this latest finding could be its most practical to date. As reported by Twitter user Mike Odyssey, a Nintendo patent filing published on October 16 would allow users with one or two Switch consoles to play Nintendo DS games via three methods. The first method was described as a "parent-and-child" setup in Nintendo's patent. In this scenario, a Switch "parent" unit would wirelessly connect to a second Switch console, which would become the "child" unit. The parent would become the DS's top screen, and the child would act as the DS's bottom screen for accessing touch controls. On paper, this method is similar to the Switch 2's GameShare functionality, which allows a host console with a supported game to share it with nearby consoles, including ones that do not have the game in question.

Two other methods would require just one Switch console, as a Picture-In-Picture mode and a Switch Screen option were also listed in Nintendo's patent. Both methods were previously utilized by the Wii U's Virtual Console lineup, which allowed DS games to be played either on the TV or the Wii U GamePad. The Wii U Virtual Console also allowed users to prioritize which DS screen to control on the GamePad, and it was configurable on a per-game basis.

With the Nintendo Switch Online periodically adding games across multiple apps, the possibility of a Nintendo DS app would add more value to the service. Needless to say, any patent filings from Nintendo should be taken with a fine pinch of salt.

item.title: Roblox: CarbiLife Codes (October 2025)
item.description:
CarbiLife offers players a Caribbean-inspired role-playing experience. You can enjoy island life however you want, whether it's a normal citizen's life or a life in the criminal underworld. But buying cars and other items will require a lot of money, so in this guide, we'll tell you how to earn extra cash with CarbiLife codes.

These Roblox codes are a great source of free cash. Almost all of them contain up to 25,000 cash, enough to purchase new equipment for your character.

All CarbiLife Codes

Working CarbiLife Codes

  • 800KVISITS - Redeem this code to get 25K Cash
  • UPDATERDY - Redeem this code to get 25K Cash
  • 900KVISITS - Redeem this code to get 25K Cash
  • DELAY! - Redeem this code to get 25K Cash
  • 2KLIKES!! - Redeem this code to get 25K Cash

Expired CarbiLife Codes

There are no expired codes in CarbiLife . We will update this article as soon as more code becomes available.

There is no tutorial in CarbiLife . You spawn right in the city, and you are free to do whatever you want. Even though you have absolutely no money in your pockets, you have access to a starter car. With it, you can not only explore the map but also perform some tasks to earn your first few bucks. However, this method is quite time-consuming, especially in the early stages. Therefore, we recommend redeeming CarbiLife codes.

The developers add codes to help and reward players. To ensure everyone can roleplay as they wish, all rewards are different amounts of money. Even a few of them are enough to earn up to 100K in just a few clicks. However, it's worth noting that codes expire after a while, and the rewards become unavailable.

How to Redeem CarbiLife Codes

The code redemption feature in CarbiLife works quite simply, so if you're familiar with other Roblox games in this genre, you'll easily figure it out. If this is your first time playing Roblox , follow these steps to redeem CarbiLife codes:

  • First, launch CarbiLife .
  • Then open Settings by clicking the gear icon at the top of the screen.
  • Next, enter the code in the appropriate field.
  • Finally, click the Redeem button to claim your reward.

How to Get More CarbiLife Codes

To avoid missing out on new CarbiLife codes, you should check out this guide, as we'll be updating it over time, just like our other Roblox codes articles. Alternatively, you can visit the developers' official social media pages. They post all the news about upcoming updates and giveaways there:

  • ChoZen Games Roblox Group
  • G.O.8 Productions Community group
Roblox
446
8.8 /10

item.title: Roblox: Lost Rooms Codes (October 2025)
item.description:
Lost Rooms is a survival horror game in which you must avoid getting killed in various locations and do everything possible to save yourself. Before each run, you can improve your character with Credits and User Credits that you receive as rewards, thus ensuring greater success in the next round.

Redeeming Lost Rooms codes is another way to get currency and resources in this Roblox title. So, if you want to upgrade your character even more without putting in too much effort, this is exactly what you need.

All Lost Rooms Codes

Working Lost Rooms Codes

  • EMOTIONS - Redeem this code to get three free Emotes.
  • FREELOSTROOMS - Redeem this code to get 200 Credits, 200 User Credits, and Banhammer

Expired Lost Rooms Codes

There are currently no expired Lost Rooms codes, so redeem active ones as soon as possible to avoid missing out on rewards.

Grinding currency and resources in Lost Rooms is not easy, especially if you are really scared of the game and its atmosphere. Redeeming Lost Rooms codes is a great alternative that will save you a lot of time and Robux.

How to Redeem Codes for Lost Rooms

Activating codes in Lost Rooms is easy, but locating the section where this can be done can be confusing, even for experienced players. To simplify the task for you, we have prepared a step-by-step guide on how to get rewards in this Roblox game:

  • Launch Lost Rooms .
  • In the main menu, pay attention to the right side of the screen. Here, under the currency counters, you will see three buttons placed in a column. Among them, interact with the second one, which says Wardrobe.
  • Once you open the new menu, look in the bottom left corner. Here, you will find the redemption section, which contains an input field and a gray 'Redeem' button next to it.
  • Now, enter one of the active codes in the input field.
  • Finally, click on the gray Redeem button to submit your request for rewards.

If everything is done correctly, a notification will appear on the screen with a list of rewards received.

How to Get More Lost Rooms Codes

If the Credits you receive from the promo codes are not enough, the best way to find more is to follow the game's official resources. That's where developers regularly publish new codes during announcements, updates, events, or other important occasions. Here are the links:

  • Official Lost Rooms Roblox group.
  • Official Lost Rooms Discord server.
Roblox

item.title: Pokemon Legends Z-A: Best Pokemon to Catch ASAP
item.description:
Pokemon Legends: Z-A has a ton of Pokemon that Trainers can pick up early and train to their heart's content; however, among them, there are a few rockstars that will carry players from Rank Z to A in the blink of an eye. If players want to smash through those A-Z Royale Battles like a force of nature, they'd better pick the better partners to create an optimized team composition ASAP.

This guide contains all the information about some of the best Pokemon players need to catch early and train to become powerful combatants in Lumiose City. From one of the most underestimated Electric-types that has made a surprising comeback thanks to its Mega Evolution, to an elusive trio of monkeys that will grant players considerable advantage in early game battles.

Mareep

Mareep can be found relatively easily in the first Wild Area players visit while completing the introductory quest. Some players might be already underestimating this Gen 2 Electric-type, but think twice, since Mareep's evolution line ends in one of the strongest Electric Pokemon in Legends Z-A: Ampharos. With the ability to use a wide assortment of SpA builds, Ampharos becomes a true menace starting at Level 30 (which is basically the level where Flaffy evolves). Mareep is a decent complement for any starter players decide to choose.

Mareep

Flaaffy

Ampharos

In the late game, Ampharos can Mega Evolve into Mega Ampharos, turning into an Electric/Dragon Pokemon, with a Base Stat Total of 610 Distributed as: 90 HP, 95 Atk, 105 Def, 165 SpA, 105 SpD, and 45 Spe. It is not the fastest nor the strongest Mega, but among the Electric-types, it has a considerable advantage thanks to its Dragon sub-typing. But here's where it gets even better: Ampharos learns Cotton Guard, which is a decent counter for melee spamming Pokemon, and can learn Hidden Power, a move that will attack with the Water-type when Ampharos is not Mega Evolved, or with the Grass-type, as Mega Ampharos. So: Lots of coverage, lots of hurt, and tons of damage with the appropriate EVs.

Eevee

Eevee is one of the Pokemon with the highest versatility in Pokemon Legends Z-A, and despite not having a new Eeveelution, it remains one of the best Pokemon to train early on. But the problem is: Where to find it? Turns out, it might be closer than what players think.

Eevee

Flareon

Jolteon

Vaporeon

Espeon

Umbreon

Leafeon

Glaceon

Sylveon

Players need to travel to the Vernal Pokemon Center, which is close to the Wild Area 1, and walk down the alley to the right from the Spawn Zone (if players fast travel). From there, follow the Pokemon Battle Cage's fence, and to the right, there will be a few Stones that players can break using Rock Smash. This will lead to a small park with a canal right in the middle. If players pay attention to the patch of green in front of them, there will be an Eevee roaming around (Lvl. 14). Enter in Stealth Mode, and throw a Quick Ball at it before it vanishes.

Dratini

Dratini is a Pokemon that requires no introduction, as many players know that it evolves into the powerful Dragonite, which has now become top of the meta thanks to its Mega Evolution being unlocked (after years of waiting). There's a way to catch Dratini early on, and it requires players to travel to Restaurant Le Nah, located in the southeastern side of Lumiose, near Vert Sector 6.

Once there, players should stand at the door and look to the building on the left. There's a ladder leading to a rooftop, and if players zoom to the opposite building (which is actually the Restaurant's rooftop), they'll be able to spot their prey. To reach that rooftop, sprint using B then Roll with Y when reaching the border. Dratini can spawn here as an Alpha, which can be quite cool to have since it has access to special moves and better stats than a regular Pokemon (plus, the maxed Size). Catching regular Dratini requires a stealth approach, save scumming, a Quick Ball, and lots of luck, but if players manage to get this Pokemon early, they are practically set for the rest of the game.

Riolu

Another fan favorite, Riolu , can be obtained relatively easily and in the earlier stages of the game (Around Lvl. 20) if players travel to the Cafe Soleil Area, near South Boulevard. Around the building, there's a ladder, and climbing it will lead to a small terrace where there's an Alpha Riolu. Save before climbing the ladder to prevent losing it, then defeat it and catch it.

Once players have secured Riolu, they should immediately take it to a Cafe or Restaurant, and drink some Tea or Coffee with it. After one or two times, Riolu's Friendship will reach the required level to evolve it into Lucario , a fearsome Fighting/Steel-type Pokemon that can use a wide array of fist attacks, and it's ideal for Sneak Attacks and ambushes during the Z-A Royale. Needless to say, Mega Lucario is also available in the game, and by adding this Pokemon to the end-game team composition, players are going to sweep through every trainer on their way to the top.

Fletchling

Another 'easy-to-underestimate' Pokemon that players can catch early in the Wild Zone 1 . Fletchling evolves into Fletchinder , and this Fire/Flying Pokemon evolves into the audacious Talonflame , one of the best Pokemon from Gen 6. Talonflame is not only fast, but dangerously powerful too. It has access to attacks like Flare Blitz, Brave Bird, and Steel Wing (most of them are Atk contact moves, which are broken on Legends Z-A ).

Fletchling

Fletchinder

Talonflame

With its powerful kit, Talonflame can carry through early and mid game, and if need be, become a decent attacker in late game, despite not having enough Base Stats to face off against powerhouses like Dragonite, Tyranitar, or Goodra. In the hands of a skilled Trainer, this Pokemon will break through most Royale Battles like a literal fireball.

Pansage, Pansear, Panpour

The Monkey Trio is back in Pokemon Legends Z-A: Pansear, Pansage, and Panpour are up for grabs, and players can find them roaming around rooftops, or perched on trees around Lumiose's streets and parks. These three monkeys are basically a complement to any starter combo, and they evolve into Simisear , Simisage , and Simipour using Evolution Stones.

These Pokemon can learn a wide array of moves of their respective types, and will be useful up to mid-game, when battles get extremely complicated and players need to carefully choose their composition to avoid becoming someone else's Ticket Points.

Your comment has not been saved

item.title: I'm Already Mourning My Pokemon Legends: Z-A Starter Choice
item.description:
Pokemon Legends: Z-A just released today for most of the world, and a lot of fans are now beginning their journey in Lumiose City or taking their time to do so over the weekend. As a massive Pokemon nerd, I have been up-to-date with everything related to Pokemon Legends: Z-A before launch, from the new battle system to Megas, because I always like to put my effort toward building optimal teams. This is something I always do because I love theorycrafting and "earning" my way to success in games. After making something like five or six possible teams for each starter in a back-and-forth moment, all optimized as much as possible, I settled on Tepig, and I deeply regret my choice.

If you are wondering which Pokemon Legends: Z-A starter to choose, stop for a second and ask yourself which one you will love the most and which one will give you the most joy. This is probably true for all games where you have to pick a character or critter, and I always find the hard way that my first playthrough is the worst anyway. That said, there are merits to each of the starters in PLZA, so I'm not saying Tepig is inherently bad. In fact, I love the little pig, and it was my first starter in Gen 5.

However, Pokemon Legends: Z-A has no new Pokemon, and it all boils down to Mega Evolutions and an exciting new battle style. Personally, I've never liked Emboar aesthetically, but I know that Meganium is still pretty bad even after some buffs, and Feraligatr just never clicked with me. So I went and took the cutesy pig for a stroll, started leveling it up, evolving it, and then it hit me I would have liked any of the other two starters more when it comes to teambuilding and aesthetics.

My Pokemon Legends: Z-A Starter is Suddenly the Worst Choice for Me

One of the reasons why I don't love Emboar is that it's inherently aggressive with its looks, but the reason I was so undecided about starters in Pokemon Legends: Z-A is that Mega Emboar is still Fire/Fighting, whereas Mega Meganium becomes Grass/Fairy, and Mega Feraligatr is Water/Dragon. I like novelty, and that's Exhibit A about why I would have been happier with either Chikorita or Totodile.

Furthermore, both Fire and Fighting have some amazing new Mega Evolutions in Pokemon Legends: Z-A , such as Chandelure and Pyroar for the former and Barbaracle, Falinks, and Hawlucha for the latter. If I have to be honest, I like all of them more than Emboar. Tepig is a different beast, but unfortunately, the game is not built for you to keep your starters as cute little babies forever. Exhibit B for why I hate my starter choice is that I desperately want to use either Chandelure or Pyroar for Fire, and most likely Falinks for Fighting, but overlapping these types with Emboar's is a bad choice.

Here is My Current Pokemon Legends: Z-A Team

Originally, my plan was to have no other Fire or Fighting-type Pokemon in the team with Emboar, but ever since I took a look at all the Megas in the game, I don't feel like that's right for me. Mega Falinks is probably one of the single best concepts for an evolution in Pokemon games ever, and Mega Pyroar reminds me of one of my three cats. I can technically still use Emboar, Pyroar, and Falinks all in one team, but that means my coverage is bad, and my weaknesses are shared among various critters. My current team is:

  • Emboar (Fire/Fighting)
  • Froslass (Ice/Ghost)
  • Victreebel (Grass/Poison)
  • Skarmory (Steel/Flying)
  • Eelektross (Electric)
  • Starmie (Water/Psychic)

By choosing Chikorita or Totodile as a starter, I would have easily been able to swap them with Victreebel or Starmie, respectively, and then replace Emboar and Eelektross with both Pyroar and Falinks, which are possibly my favorite new Megas. Mega Starmie may be the best new Mega Evolution in Pokemon Legends: Z-A , and while Mega Meganium's movepool is dreadful, choosing Chikorita may have been the best option for me so that I could keep Starmie on the team, too.

I Am Officially Putting My Pokemon Legends: Z-A Starter in a Box

Instead, now I find myself struggling with what to keep and what to do, exactly, to the point that I am considering changing my team drastically, and committing the ultimate Pokemon sin - removing my starter from the team. While you can catch the other starters in the game, I haven't found them yet, and it's not exactly the same thing. So, my plan would be to use an entirely different team that doesn't include Mega Emboar in Pokemon Legends: Z-A . It would be as follows:

  • Mega Pyroar (Fire/Normal, special attacker)
  • Mega Falinks (Fighting, physical attacker)
  • Mega Skarmory (Steel/Flying, physical attacker)
  • Mega Starmie (Water/Psychic, hybrid attacker)
  • Mega Victreebel (Grass/Poison, special attacker)
  • Mega Excadrill (Ground/Steel, physical attacker)

At that point, my team-wide defenses would look like this:

Pokemon

Bug

Dark

I know that this could all be a massive pet peeve on my end, but between disliking both base Emboar and Mega Emboar and liking two Pokemon with overlapping types much more, I feel like cutting my starter from the team is simply the most sensible option. After all, the game should be fun, even if it means leaving one's first partner Pokemon behind. I find that very sad, and that's why I'm struggling, but at the same time, I think it's for the best.

5.2 /10
